detall.title: Open day at the Generalitat and Catalan Parliament
detall.excerpt: To mark the commemoration of 11 September, the Palau de la Generalitat and the Palau del Parlament will be holding an open day.
detall.content:
The Palau de la Generalitat, the seat of the Catalan regional government, and the Palau del Parlament [Catalan Parliament building] will both be holding an open day on 11 September from 10 am to 7 pm, when everyone can come along and visit them.

The opening of the Catalan Parliament to mark Catalan National Day is a tradition started by the Catalan chamber following the re-establishment of that institution, on 1980. The Saló de Sessions [semi-circular auditorium where parliament sits], conference rooms, offices, the Saló de Passos Perduts hall and the Escalinata d’Honor [outside "staircase of honour"] are just a few of the spaces and rooms that can be examined by visitors to the Palau, built during the first half of the 18th century as Ciutadella’s storehouse and today the seat of the chamber.

Meanwhile, the Catalan History Museum will be holding open days from 6 to 11 September to mark Antoni Estruch’s exhibition entitled Eleventh of September 1714, one of the most emblematic works making up the iconography of the Defeat of 11 September. It represents the moment when Barcelona’s Commander-in-Chief, Rafael Casanova, fell from a bullet wound, while hoisting the flag of St Eulalia, on the morning of 11 September 1714.
detall.author: José María Dempere
